arm_group.description: Patients who have undergone resection of tumor tissue
Patients who have not undergone resection of tumor tissue

brief_summary.textblock:
Anatomical changes that take place during Intensity modulated radiation therapy (IMRT)
      treatments for cancers of the head and neck cause significant dosimetric changes.

clinical_study.brief_title: Serial CT Based Imaging for the Detection of Dosimetric Changes During Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy (IMRT) for Advanced Cancers of the Head and Neck
condition: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigator's hypothesis is that those patients with bulky head and neck cancers who
      undergo definitive radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy have changes in their dose
      distribution that lead to significant changes in dose to tumor and/or normal tissue.  It is
      possible for these dosimetric changes could occur in either those patients who undergo
      resection or not. In this study those patients who have undergone a resection will be
      stratified separately for analysis, however, this study is not powered to detect a
      difference between the two groups.  The rational for stratification into an operated group
      of patients is that these patients will also lose weight in treatment and will provide us a
      detection of the magnitude of change in dose caused by weight loss independent of tumor
      shrinkage.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  AJCC pathological stage I-IV cancers of the head and neck meeting the following
             criteria:

               -  If gross total resection is performed it must be completed within 7 weeks of
                  registration

          -  Site of tumor origin in the nasopharynx, oral cavity, oropharynx, parotid, larynx, or
             hypopharynx (excluding lip, or sinuses)

          -  Pretreatment evaluations required for eligibility include:

               -  History and physical examination within four weeks prior to study entry

               -  Dental evaluation with management according to the guidelines in Appendix IV
                  prior to start of radiation

               -  Serum pregnancy test, if applicable, within one week prior to study entry; urine
                  dipstick test on the first day of treatment

               -  Radiographic Studies:  Pre-operative CT or MRI of the primary tumor and neck for
                  clinical staging is required

          -  Patients must be ≥ 18 years of age.

          -  Women of childbearing potential (WOCBP) must be willing to consent to using effective
             contraception while on treatment.

          -  Pregnant women are ineligible as radiation therapy involves unforeseeable risks to
             the embryo or fetus.  WOCBP must have a negative serum or urine pregnancy test
             (minimum sensitivity 25 IU/L or equivalent units of human chorionic gonadotropin
             [hCG], or in accordance with local regulations, whichever is more sensitive).

          -  Patients must sign a study-specific informed consent form prior to registration.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Histology positive for melanoma.

          -  Gross (visible or palpable) disease left after surgery.

          -  Less than gross total resection or patients requiring staged surgery.

          -  Prior head and neck radiotherapy.

          -  Women of childbearing potential (WOCBP) who are unwilling or unable to use an
             acceptable method to avoid pregnancy for the entire study period

study_pop.textblock:
Patients with pathologic stage I-IV cancers of the head and neck (site of tumor origin
        nasopharynx, parotid, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, or hypopharynx,)  either following
        gross total resection and requiring postoperative XRT for high-risk features or undergoing
        definitive concurrent chemo-radiation.

intervention.description: Patients will be enrolled in study through the duration of their radiation therapy, approximately 5-8 weeks.  After which time no further evaluations will be made.

Treatment planning CT scans will be required to define tumor, clinical, and planning target volumes. This study requires CT scans prior to initiation of treatment then again on the third and sixth week of radiation treatment

keyword: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Observational Trial of Serial CT Based Imaging for the Detection of Dosimetric Changes During Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy (IMRT) for Advanced Cancers of the Head and Neck

overall_official.affiliation: University of Miami Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: To evaluate whether those patients undergoing standard intensity modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) for bulky head and neck cancers demonstrate significant anatomic changes during treatment which lead to under-dosing of tumor and/or over dosing of critical structures.
primary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients Demonstrating Anatomic Changes During IMRT

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: To determine whether patients undergoing standard IMRT for head and neck cancers require re-planning during the course of therapy.
secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Requiring Re-Planning During the Course of IMRT for Head and Neck Cancer

secondary_outcome.description: To estimate what the appropriate time course should be for re-planning of radiation therapy if it is deemed necessary.
secondary_outcome.measure: Length of Time Required for Replanning of Radiation Therapy

clinical_study.source: University of Miami Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center
